original_data.question: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of worsening grades over the past year. Since she started high school one year ago, her academic performance has decreased. She also has had difficulty finding friends at the new school. She is afraid that her classmates will make fun of her and think that she is “stupid.” One month ago, when she had to give a presentation, she could not stop wondering how her classmates were going to react if she said something wrong. During the presentation, her heart started racing and she became flushed. Since this event, she avoids saying anything in class. She spends her breaks in the restroom because she is worried that nobody will talk to her. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, the girl avoids eye contact and appears uncomfortable and anxious. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition?

model_response:
The girl's history is suggestive of social anxiety disorder. The most effective pharmacotherapy for this condition is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). Fluoxetine is a good choice because it is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for use in children. Clomipramine is also an effective antianxiety agent but is not approved by the FDA for use in children. Propranolol is a beta blocker that is sometimes used to decrease the physiologic symptoms of anxiety (e.g., tremor, palpitations, sweating). However, it is not a first-line treatment for social anxiety disorder. Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) that is also used to treat anxiety disorders. However, because of dietary restrictions and potential drug interactions, MAOIs are usually reserved for treatment-resistant patients.

###COMMENT: Clomipramine is effective in the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, because it has not been shown to be effective in children and adolescents with OCD, it is not a first-line treatment for this condition in this age group.

###COMMENT: Propranolol is used to decrease the physiologic symptoms of anxiety (e.g., tremor, palpitations, sweating). However, it is not a first-line treatment for social anxiety disorder.

###COMMENT: MAOIs are usually reserved for treatment-resistant patients because of dietary restrictions and potential drug interactions.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Female parents, human or animal.
A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A secondary school that usually includes grades 9 through 12.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A quantitative or qualitative measure of intellectual, scholarly, or scholastic accomplishment.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

A cognitive disorder marked by an impaired ability to comprehend or express language in its written or spoken form. This condition is caused by diseases which affect the language areas of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical features are used to classify the various subtypes of this condition. General categories include receptive, expressive, and mixed forms of aphasia.
Educational institutions.
A member of the same class at school.
Every month.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
A member of the same class at school.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.
Something that happens at a given place and time.
A grouping of things based on shared common attributes.
Interruptions in the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA.
Facilities containing equipment for disposal of human excrement, often with an accompanying hand-washing station.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Assessment of sensory and motor responses and reflexes that is used to determine impairment of the nervous system.

A standardized and structured interview originally developed by Marshal Folstein, Susan Folstein and Paul McHugh (Journal of Psychiatric Research, 1975), which is used to evaluate an individual's cognitive function.
Feelings or emotions of dread, apprehension, and impending disaster but not disabling as with ANXIETY DISORDERS.
The use of DRUGS to treat a DISEASE or its symptoms. One example is the use of ANTINEOPLASTIC AGENTS to treat CANCER.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
